PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name Lawrence Irwin HOCKLEY b. Feb. 11, 1893
Address Box 339, Indian Head, Saskatchewan
Birthplace Fort Qu'Appelle, Saskatchewan (on Pasqua Indian reservation)

Father was farm instructor on Fort Qu'Appelle Indian reservations. My father, William Stewart Hockley, was married 1864.

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1893

With my elder brothers, I batched in Wide Awake district as early as 1902, where we had just acquired land. About 1908, I batched with an elder brother on his homestead 10 miles north of Osage, south of Indian Head.

Where had you been living before that? Except for brief periods on the homesteads of my brothers, I have lived in Wide Awake S.D., north of Indian Head, since 1902.

For how many people did you prepare meals? Before that I lived with my parents on the Pasqua Indian reserve. Generally we prepared meals for two - myself and a brother.

How far was it to your nearest store? In Wide Awake S.D., the nearest store was about 10 miles (Indian Head); at Osage the store would be about 10 miles (Osage).

How often could a visit be made to the store? We visited the store about every two weeks on the average.

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Staples like flour, dried fruits (prunes, apples), salt, syrups (corn); we raised chickens usually for eggs or got eggs at neighbours'; bread was purchased, when possible, at a neighbour's; we had a cow for milk; we sometimes brought potatoes from home or bought them at neighbour's.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Local flour milled in Indian Head at Wilson's mill.

We usually took our own grain in to be ground.

In what quantities did you buy it? The total supply of flour ground in this way was called a "Grist." Often we would get a ton made in this way.

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? The service of grinding was paid for percentage of flour called a "toll."

How much did you use graham flour? It was not used much.

Whole wheat flour? Occasionally.

Was flour milled locally? Yes. How far away? At least 1902 when we moved to Wide Awake. On Pasqua reserve my father got his flour in the form of rations supplied by the Government.

What other grain products did you use? None other of importance.

Cornmeal? Occasionally. Whole Wheat? Occasionally. Farina? Occasionally.

Mother used to make Johnny cake.

Other? Oatmeal was the staple porridge meal.

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No.

How did you grind it? **

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, SASK, where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our province.

Name Lawrence Irwin HOCKLEY
b. Feb. 11, 1892

Address Box 379, Indian Head, Saskatchewan

Birthplace Fort Qu'Appelle, Saskatchewan (on Pasqua Indian reservation)

Father was farm instructor on Fort Qu'Appelle Indian reservations by father William Stewart Hockley

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start homesteading? 1894

With my elder brothers, I homesteaded in the same district as myself, near Indian Head. I bought with my elder brother on his homestead 10 miles north of Indian Head.

Where had you been living before that? I lived in the town of Indian Head, since 1902.

My brothers, I have lived in the town of Indian Head, since 1902.

For how many people did you prepare meals? Before that, I helped my parents on the Pasqua Indian reserve. Generally we prepared meals for two—myself and a storekeeper.

How often could a visit be made to the store? We visited the store about every two weeks on the average.

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Staples like flour or eggs or got eggs at neighbours'.

Children usually for eggs or got eggs at neighbours'. Bread was purchased when possible, at a neighbour's; we had a cow for milk; we sometimes brought potatoes from home or bought them at neighbours'.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Local flour milled in Indian Head at Willson's mill.

In what quantities did you buy it? We usually took our own grain in to be ground.

Was called a "gristmill". Often we would get a ton made in this way.

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of flour? The service of grinding was paid for percentage of flour called a "roll".

How much did you use graham flour? It was not used much.

Whole wheat flour? Yes, but not much.

Was flour milled locally? Yes, but not much.

How far away? At least 1902 when we moved to Waskesiu.

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.50.

Price was quite reasonable.

What other grain products did you use? None other than graham flour.

Occasionally oatmeal, occasionally porridge, occasionally.

Other? Oatmeal, yes, the staple, porridge, meal.

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No.

How did you grind it?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ...beef, pork, a lot of wild fowl - prairie chicken & duck, a lot of fish...........................................

How often did you get fresh meat? ...Frequently. It was not hard to come by...except when it was unattainable in summer when we usually relied on salt pork.

This form was made out and dictated to me by my father L.J. Hockley shortly before his death Jan 14, 1967. ...Tams. S. Hockley
3. Sugars and syrups

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ... 100 lbs. annually.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? ... approximately $15.00 or $6.

What brand of golden syrup did you use? ... Armstrong No. 20, 4 lb. size, $2.50.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ... 1 lb.

At what price? ... $1.00.

4. Dairy products

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? ... We had to milk our own cows.

Did you make butter? ... Yes.

Did you pack eggs for winter? ... Yes.

Did you make butter? ... Yes.

What kind of cheese? ... Cottage cheese.

5. Meat and fish

What was your meat supply in the early years? ... Beef, pork, a lot of salted beef.

How did you get fresh meat? ... Raised cattle, chickens, pigs; also a lot of hunting for wild game and a lot of fishing in the Calumet lakes.

How did you preserve meat? ... Canned it (beef), pork was salted or preserved in salt brine; in the winter meat was frozen.

Was there a "beer ring" in your neighborhood? ... Not before 1921.

If so what year was it organized? ... 1921.

Did you use game? ... Yes.

For how long? ... All the time - no out of season, except we would not go out westing.

What part did fish play in the family diet? ... Mainly larger perch, as we were near the lakes; in the winter, it played about as large a part as beef.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ... Always fresh.

Kinda? ... Pickerel, pike, white fish.

This form was worked on by me by my folks. L. S. Hockley

March 14, 1967 - James S. Hockley
